_header: The first stock father of gentilesse
Note:
Inserted also in Scogan’s ‘Moral Balade’, for which see 3645; in one manuscript with two-couplet epilogue; unattributed editions, Anderson (1793)
XAnderson, Robert. The Works of the British Poets, or, Complete Edition of the Poets of Great Britain. 13 vols. Vol. 1. Edinburgh, 1793; London, 1795, 1.579; Clarke (1835)
XClarke, Charles Cauder. The Riches of Chaucer. London: T. Tegg, 1835, 1839, 2.306.
_description: Geoffrey Chaucer, ‘Gentilesse’ — three stanzas rhyme royal

BodAsh59.First Lines:
þe first fader and foundour of gentylesseWhat man þat
                    claymeþe gentyle for to beMoste felowe hees traas and alle hees wittes
                    dresseVertue to suwe and vyces for to flee…
BodAsh59.Last Lines:
…þat maþe his heyre him þat wol him qwemeAl
                    were he mytre crowne or dyademe
BodAsh59.Note:
The poem is inserted between stanzas 13 and 14 of Scogan’s
                    ‘Moral Balade’ (3645).
BodAsh59.Attributed Author:
Geffrey Chaucier made þeos thre balades nexst þat folowen (f.
                    27)
BodAsh59.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             A Parallel-Text Edition of Chaucer’s Minor Poems.
             3 vols. 
             Chaucer Society
         1st. ser. 21, 57, 58. London: Trübner, n.d. repr. New York and
            London: Johnson, 1967. 
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             A One-Text Print of the Minor Poems.
         2 pts. London: Trübner, 1871, 1880; repr. New York and London:
            Johnson, 1967. 
Chambers,  Edmund Kerchever,  and  Frank Sidgwick.  
             Early English Lyrics….
         London: Buller, 1907, 1911 et seq: 174.
Forni,  Kathleen,
                        ed.  
             The Chaucerian
                    Apocrypha: A Selection.
         Kalamazoo, MI: Western Michigan University for TEAMS, 2005.

CULGg4271b.First Lines:
The first stoke father of gentilnesWhat man desireth gentill for to
                    be…
CULGg4271b.Last Lines:
…that made them gentlemen I called beeAnd bidd vs followe them
                    in such degree
CULGg4271b.Note:
Late (seventeenth-century) copy from Speght (1598)
XSpeght,  Thomas. 
             The Workes of…Geffrey Chaucer.
         London, [A. Islip,] imp. G. Bishop, 1598; rev. ed. A. Islip, 1602 (STC
            5077, 5080); adds a
                    fourth stanza, unique.
CULGg4271b.Facsimiles:
Parkes,  Malcolm B.,  and  Richard Beadle.  
             “Introduction.” 
             Poetical Works. Geoffrey Chaucer. A Facsimile of Cambridge University
                Library MS Gg.4.27. 3 vols Cambridge: D. S. Brewer, 1979 (vol. 1); 1980 (vols. 2-3).

CamTCC600.First Lines:
Þe first fader fynder of gentylesseWhat man desyreþe
                    gentyl for to beMote filowe heos traces and alle heos wittes
                    dresseVertue to suwe and vyces for to flee…
CamTCC600.Last Lines:
…Þat makeþe heos heyres hem þat wel him
                    qweemeAl weyre þey mytre corone or dyadeeme
CamTCC600.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             A Parallel-Text Edition of Chaucer’s Minor Poems.
             3 vols. 
             Chaucer Society
         1st. ser. 21, 57, 58. London: Trübner, n.d. repr. New York and
            London: Johnson, 1967.

CamTCC921.First Lines:
The first stake fadre of gentylnesWh[ ]lk kleymyht gentyl for to
                    be…
CamTCC921.Last Lines:
…And [ ] R[ ]f savely dar y deme[ ]yhter croune or
                    deyodeme
CamTCC921.Note: One stanza only; part of text lost due to damp.

BLCottCleoDVII.First Lines:
The firste stock fader of gentilnesseWhat man desireth gentil for
                    to be…
BLCottCleoDVII.Last Lines:
…That maketh his heires hem that hym quemeAll were he myter
                    Coroune or dyademe

BLHar2251.First Lines:
The first stok was fader of gentilnesAnd who that claymeth gentil
                    for to be…
BLHar2251.Last Lines:
…That makith his Eyre suche as can hym qweumeWhether he were
                    myter crowne or dyademe
BLHar2251.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             A Parallel-Text Edition of Chaucer’s Minor Poems.
             3 vols. 
             Chaucer Society
         1st. ser. 21, 57, 58. London: Trübner, n.d. repr. New York and
            London: Johnson, 1967.

BLHar7333.First Lines:
ÞE ffirste fadir & fynder of gentilnessewhat man desireith
                    gentil for to be…
BLHar7333.Last Lines:
…Whech maþe his herres hem þat doone him quemeAl
                    were he mytre corone or dyademe
BLHar7333.Note:
The ‘e’ is written over a ‘y’ in the final word,
                    ‘dyademe’. This item precedes Truth (1326) on f.
                        147vb).
BLHar7333.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             A Parallel-Text Edition of Chaucer’s Minor Poems.
             3 vols. 
             Chaucer Society
         1st. ser. 21, 57, 58. London: Trübner, n.d. repr. New York and
            London: Johnson, 1967.

BLHar7578.First Lines:
The first strooke fader of gentelnesseWhat man desireth gentel for
                    to bee…
BLHar7578.Last Lines:
…That maketh his eyres hem that him quemeAlle were he myter
                    corowne or diademe

BLAdd22139.First Lines:
The firste stok fader of gentilnesseWhat mani that coueyteth gentil
                    for to be…
BLAdd22139.Last Lines:
…That maketh his eires hem that can him quemeAll were he mitre
                    corone or diademe
BLAdd22139.Note: Follows immediately after 6044, and immediately before 4990.
BLAdd22139.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.

             Chaucer Society
         1st. ser. 21, 57, 58. London: Trübner, n.d. repr. New York and
            London: Johnson, 1967.

CovAcc3251.First Lines:
The first stokke fadir of gentilnesseWhat man þat coueitith
                    gentil to be…
CovAcc3251.Last Lines:
…That makith his Ewis hem þat can hym quemeAll were he
                    myter croos or diademe

NottsULMeLm1.First Lines:
The firste stokke fader of gentylnesseWhat man that cleymeth
                    gentyll for to beMuste felowe hys tras and hys wyttes dresseVertu to
                    love and vices for to fflee…
NottsULMeLm1.Last Lines:
…Al were he mytur crowne or dyademeWho that hath troweth pyte
                    fredam & hardynesHe ys a man enherytode in gentylnesOf these
                    fowere vertues who þat laketh threCald gentylman he oweth not for to
                    be
NottsULMeLm1.Note:
Added by hand of the fifteenth century, adding four-line stanza, two
                    couplets.
NottsULMeLm1.Editions:
Davis,  Norman. 
             “Chaucer’s Gentilesse: A Forgotten Manuscript with some
                Proverbs.” 
             Review of English Studies
         20 (1969): 43-50: 46-7.
